Authors: Suman Keerthi, Uma Devi Koduru, Sarma S Nittala
Title:
Ribosomal DNA typing in the genus Dunaliella (Chlorophyceae) 
A reliable barcode for species identification?
Keywords:
18S rRNA gene, carotenogenic Dunaliella, D. salina,
introns, ITS regions, phylogenetic analysis, rDNA primers
Abstract:
Dunaliella salina (Dunal)Teodoresco, a unicellular cell
wall less halophilic commercially important microalga is difficult to
identify based on morphology. Typing rDNA is reported as a means for its
identification. Sixteen carotenogenic Dunaliella isolates from south
east Indian coast were rDNA typed. Primers specific for 18S rRNA of
chlorophycean microalgae also amplified the 18S rRNA of ciliate grazer-
Euplotes euryhalinus Valbonesi & Luporini in Dunaliella cultures.
The position of the primers developed for amplification of whole length
18S rRNA gene and species specific introns in Dunaliella was also found
to differ in different Dunaliella isolates. Carotenogenic Dunaliella
isolates with and without an intron in 18S rRNA gene were found. Among
the Dunaliella isolates with one intron, some were found to have intron
1 type described in a majority of D. salina isolates while some had
intron 2 type found in Dunaliella species with two introns and D. salina
ABRIINW-M1/2 strain. Two types of ITS1 not previously recognized in
Dunaliella were discovered. They were amplified from B32 isolate as
~650bp and ~500bp products; the former matched several ITS sequences
from Dunaliella species and the latter showed similarity with sequences
accessioned as ITS1 from D. bardawil Ben-Amotz & Avron (a nomen
nudum of D. salina) and D. viridis Teodoresco . This ITS1 had sequence
similarity over some length with U6RNA gene with transposon activity.
Analysis of highly conserved region of ITS2 region from B32 and I3
isolates revealed great differences with six compensatory base changes
between them and eight with other D. salina isolates compared.
Phylogenetic analysis of 18S rRNA and ITS15.8S rRNAITS2 sequences showed
no clustering of D. salina isolates. The genetic distances between
Dunaliella species within carotenogenous and non carotenogenous group
far exceeded the differences between the two groups. Thus rDNA typing
was found not suitable for identification of D. salina. The primers
developed for characterization of rDNA were found to be neither genus
nor species specific.
